In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  an  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  consultation  mission  in  Viet  Nam,  the 
Government of Viet Nam requested that ADB assist it in increasing the efficiency of the newly 
established  National  Power  Transmission  Corporation  (NPT)  in  order  to  improve  the 
implementation of transmission projects. The concept paper for this technical assistance (TA) 
was approved on 9 July 2010. A fact-finding mission visited Viet Nam on 28 July 2010 and 
reached an understanding with the government on the impact, outcome, output, implementation 
arrangement, cost, and terms of reference for the TA.1 The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Vietnamese Electricity Law assigns to the Ministry of Industry and Trade (MOIT) the 
responsibility for restructuring and developing the power market. In October 2005, by prime 
minister’s decision (258/2005/QD-TTg) the Electricity Regulatory Authority of Viet Nam (ERAV) 
was established under the MOIT. ERAV functions include (i) issuing and enforcing electricity 
licenses, (ii) advising the minister on market structure and policy, (iii) establishing retail tariff 
setting  principles  and  mechanisms,  (iv)  proposing  the  market  design  and  developing  the 
associated regulatory framework, (v) approving the power purchase agreement of the single 
buyer, (vi) monitoring the progress of the implementation of new generation and transmission 
projects,  (vii)  monitoring  the  operation  of  the  power  market,  and  (viii)  monitoring  (and 
recommendations to protect) the short and long-term energy balance. 
   
3.   The Electricity Law describes the transition period from a vertically integrated structure 
to  a  market-orientated  structure  though  three  successive  market  phases:  (i)  a  generation 
competitive market under a single buyer (in 2010), (ii) a wholesale competitive market (in 2014), 
and (iii) a retail competitive market (in 2020). 
 
4.   Directly  or  through  subsidiaries,  Electricity  Vietnam  (EVN)  owns  or  is  the  majority 
shareholder of most generation capacity, the 500 kilovolt (kV) / 220 kV transmission system, the 
National  Load  Dispatch  Center,  and  the  power  companies  that  are  the  main  distribution 
companies with medium-voltage and some low-voltage distribution system to the urban areas 
and some rural areas. Power companies sell to independent local distribution utilities that 
distribute through low-voltage networks and retail in rural and distant areas. 
 
5.   In  line  with  this  sector  reform  plan,  the  government  approved  EVN’s  proposal  to 
establish the NPT on 1 July 2008. The NPT is a fully state-owned single member limited liability 
company under EVN and is officially in operation. The NPT is responsible for the investment  
and  construction,  operation,  and  maintenance  of  the  transmission  network  in  Viet  Nam, 
including 220 kV and 500 kV lines and associated substations.  
 
6.   EVN  has  also  established  the  Power  Trading  Company  (EPTC)  as  a  financial 
dependent member. The EPTC undertakes the task of purchasing electricity from power plants 
via  the  power  market  or  via  long-term  power  purchase  agreements,  and  wholesaling  to 
distribution companies.  
 
                                                 
1 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 2 September 2010.

2  
7.  The National Load Dispatch Center is an EVN-dependent unit in charge of continuously 
and reliably guaranteeing the quality of supply and ensuring the most economical operation of 
the power system.  
 
8.  In August 2008, in line with the implementation plan for the power market approved by 
the government, ERAV issued draft electricity market regulations, detailing the methodology for 
calculating  the  charges  of  the  transmission  and  system  market  operator,  i.e.,  EPTC,  in  a 
generation competitive power market. ERAV has requested the NPT and the system market 
operator to review and comment on the draft electricity market regulations and to provide it with 
technical input needed to introduce these regulations, at first on a pilot basis, in early 2011 in 
order to have the full generation competitive market operational by late 2011.  
 
9.  Since the NPT has only recently been established, there is a lack of practical experience 
of power market, and it has requested ADB assistance for (i) commenting on ERAV draft 
regulations  and  assisting  the  NPT  during  further  discussion  on  this  topic;  (ii)  through 
benchmarking with the model in use in other countries, assisting the NPT in computing the 
operational costs and corresponding transmission charges; (iii) training NPT staff in this respect; 
and  (iv)  providing  a  recommendation  on  an  adequate  institutional  structure  of  the  NPT 
compatible  with  the  new  market-oriented  power  sector.  Technical  assistance  (TA)2  was 
provided to the NPT in 2009 and considerable progress was made, enabling the NPT to make 
its  first  submission  to  ERAV  in  December  2009  with  the  computation  of  the  transmission 
expenses and a proposed tariff for transmission charges. Since then, ERAV has been refining 
the regulation documentation, and issued a new draft on 27 January 2010. It is anticipated that, 
until the generation competitive market is in place in late 2011, there will be some other 
iterations on the regulation, for which the NPT will need further assistance. 
 
10.   The level of the NPT’s allowed revenue is the most crucial data for the NPT, because 
transmission charges are its main source of income. If the transmission charges are too low, the 
NPT will not be able to implement its investment plan and won’t be able to meet the future 
financial requirement. Because of the current high growth in the power sector in Viet Nam, the 
NPT will have to develop the transmission system very quickly. Capital expenditure will form a 
significant proportion of the costs to be recovered through the transmission charges. This could 
represent almost half of the NPT’s total cost structure in the coming years. Therefore it is crucial 
for the NPT to optimize its investment plan and capital expenditure.  
 
11.  From 2011 to 2016, to meet the actual growth in power demand of 15% annually, the 
NPT needs to invest about $750 million annually in new transmission assets. Taking into 
account the huge annual investment and the fact that the NPT was only recently incorporated 
(July 2008), there is a need to plan carefully. As such, development of a 5-year business plan is 
crucial to NPT management having a financial tool that will enable them to efficiently plan the 
required investment, and it needs to be regularly updated.  
 
12.  Based on ongoing ADB-financed operations with the NPT, important delays in project 
implementation were noted that have led to an additional financial burden for the NPT due to 
increased commitment charges. Among the various causes of delays in implementation, two 
main reasons have been identified: (i) lack of proper skill in terms of planning and project 
management, and (ii) delay introduced by lengthy process in involuntary resettlement and land 
acquisition. The proposed TA will address these issues by providing training, guidelines, and

Transmission Corporation in a Competitive Power Market Environment. Manila.

3
procedures for the project implementation unit and by developing communication tools to be 
used by the NPT in negotiating with the regional government and the population. 
 
13.  This TA will complement the assistance provided by other development partners in the 
power sector. The World Bank is providing assistance to ERAV for the development of the 
transmission  charges  methodology,  a  grid  code,  and  for  the  design  of  the  generation 
competitive market in Viet Nam. The Agence Française de Développement is financing a long-
term advisor to the ERAV, whose main tasks are to coordinate the tasks and works of the 
various consultants involved in the power sector reform, and to assist the MOIT to develop the 
energy efficiency law. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact will be to facilitate the development of a market-driven power sector that is 
contributing to sustainable market growth. Indicators will be based on the electricity tariffs and 
the increase of investment in the power generation sector from nonstate sources. The outcome 
of the TA will be to enable the NPT to have an adequate and efficient organizational structure 
that  matches  the  requirement  of  the  new  power  sector  regulations  and  achieves  financial 
viability by 2015.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.   The four outputs of the TA will improve the daily operation of the NPT by providing (i) 
technical inputs as required by the ERAV for the computation of the transmission charges, (ii) a 
5-year business plan, (iii) training of NPT staff on project management procedures, and (iv) a 
communication strategy and guidelines. The outputs will be achieved through the following 
activities. 
 
16.  Transmission charges and regulation. Under this activity the consultant will (i) review 
and provide comments to the NPT on the regulations issued by ERAV, and (ii) provide training 
to the NPT staff on the understanding and the use of these ERAV regulations. The TA will also 
help the NPT compute the transmission charges for submission to ERAV based on the NPT 
operational expenses, capital expenditures, and the related financial charges. A 5-year business 
plan (2011–2016) of the company will be developed under the TA. 
 
17.  Financial  management. The TA will provide the NPT with an appropriate financial 
model for the computation of the transmission charges based on the latest regulations issued by 
ERAV. Training in the use and maintenance of the model will also be provided. 
  
18.  Project management. The TA will provide training to at least 40 project staff on the use 
of  project  management  tools  and  planning,  procurement,  and  administration  of  investment 
projects by 2011. 
 
19.  Communication.  The  TA  will  provide  the  NPT  with  the  required  tools  such  as  a 
communication strategy, procedure, and website. The aim is to improve the NPT’s external 
communication  with  the  local  government  as  well  as  with  the  population  during  project 
preparation, implementation, and operation by 2011.

4  
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $720,000 equivalent. The government has 
requested ADB to finance $600,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will finance the 
remaining $120,000 in kind to cover counterpart costs and services including counterpart staff, 
office space, conference rooms, and telephone and internet lines. The detailed financing plan is 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  The NPT will be the executing agency for this project. ADB has requested the NPT to set 
up an NPT internal working team for the TA, which will include senior staff from planning, 
business, accounting, financing, and project departments.  
 
22.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
23.  The TA will require about 25 person-months of international and national consulting 
services. Four individual international consultants and one individual national consultant will be 
engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The international team will comprise a power regulatory advisor (8 
person-months), a financial analyst (4 person-months), a project management specialist (4 
person-months), and a communication specialist (3 person-months). A national communication 
specialist will be required for 6 person-months. The TA will be completed in 18 months, from 
October 2010 to April 2012. Outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. There will not be any 
procurement of goods under the TA. 
 
24.  The expected impact, outcome, output, and activities of the TA will be monitored through 
ADB review missions and reports to be produced during the TA. Quarterly progress reports will 
be produced during the life of the TA and a draft final report will be produced in March 2012 for 
the regulation activities and financial strengthening of the NPT, and in December 2011 for the 
project management and communication strategy activities. Final reports will be finalized 1 
month later after incorporating the comments received. Dissemination of the output will be done 
through the NPT website.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for Increasing the Efficiency of the National Power Transmission 
Corporation through Targeted Capacity Building, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.   The implementation of the technical assistance (TA) will require the services of a team 
of individual consultants in the fields of the three main subjects that the TA intends to cover (i) 
assistance in the establishment of a competitive power generation market, (ii) improvement of 
National Power Transmission Corporation (NPT) efficiency in implementing investment projects, 
and (iii) improvement of communication skills within the NPT.  
 
2.  The consultants will be engaged by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) as individual 
consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time). The TA will start in October 2010 and run for 18 months until April 2012. 
Performance of the consultants will be evaluated by ADB in coordination with the NPT. 
 
A.  Power Regulatory Advisor (international, 8 person-months) and Financial Analyst 
(international, 4 person-months)  
3.  The  power  regulations advisor  and  the  financial  expert  will  work closely  with  other 
consultants in charge of the reform of the power sector, the Ministry of Industry and Trade 
(MOIT), the Electricity Regulatory Agency of Viet Nam (ERAV), Vietnam Electricity (EVN), their 
consultants and advisors, and other agencies. The tasks of the advisor and the financial expert 
are divided into five different components: 
(i)  assist NPT during negotiations of the transmission-related regulations with ERAV, 
(ii)  implement the transmission regulations within the NPT, 
(iii)  improve the financial model for the computation of the transmission charges that 
was developed under the former small scale technical assistance, 
(iv)  strengthen the NPT financial management, and 
(v)  update the 5-year business plan developed under a previous TA1 based on the 
new forecast of the Power Master Plan No.7 currently under development. 
1.  Specific Tasks 
4.  The specialists will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Comment  on  and  assist  NPT  during  its  discussions  with  ERAV  of    the 
transmission-related regulations: 
(a) Review and comment on the transmission regulation and the grid code 
issued by ERAV. Propose changes if necessary. 
(b) The commenting will include critical review of the provided documentation 
from the perspective of supporting NPT’s independence and ensuring 
consideration  of  NPT’s  interests  as  well  as  the  ability  of  the  NPT  to 
implement the proposed regulation. It will provide the NPT with technical, 
financial,  and  other  argumentation  necessary  for  the  NPT  to  be  in  a 
position to discuss the said documentation with ERAV. 
(c) Attend joint meetings between ERAV, their consultants, advisors, and the 
NPT as well as any other meetings as requested by the NPT.

(ii)  Implement the transmission regulation within the NPT: 
 
(a) Provide guidance to the NPT in improving its organization in order to 
follow the transmission regulation more efficiently and proactively. 
(b) Provide  guidance  to  the  NPT  in  regularly  reviewing  the  transmission 
regulation implementation in order to propose improvement if necessary. 
(c) Train a permanent team in the NPT to follow closely the transmission 
regulation and to manage all of its components. 
(d) Assist the NPT in calculating the transmission network operator revenue. 
Train NPT staff in providing several sets of assumptions, and calculating 
every quarter the corresponding allowed revenue based on updated data. 
(e) Compare NPT’s computation with ERAV assessment, and identify and 
explain the gaps between its own and ERAV’s estimates. Provide the 
NPT with explanations and argumentation for further discussions with 
ERAV. 
(f)  Provide guidance to the NPT in calculating transmission charges based 
on the approved regulation. 
(g) Assist the NPT to identify the transmission failures under its control and to 
propose an acceptable method for calculating transmission penalties. 
(h) List the reports and data that the NPT will have to submit regularly to 
ERAV. Draw up an annual schedule with detailed tasks to be carried out 
by the NPT in order to meet the regulation requirements and to provide 
feedback on the transmission implementation. 
(i)  Provide guidance to the NPT in adapting the network access contracts to 
the transmission regulation. 
(iii)  Improve the financial model for the computation of the transmission charges that 
was developed under the previous TA project: 
(a) Improve the financial model developed under the former TA by adapting it 
to the approved regulation, adding more flexibility and making it more 
user-friendly. 
(b) Work closely with the NPT to ensure that this model is adapted to NPT’s 
practices and takes into account NPT’s needs so that it can be used as a 
working tool. 
(c) Provide a user guide. 
(iv)  Strengthen the NPT financial management: 
(a) Provide guidance to the NPT in finding different solutions to improve its 
financial  position  and  balance  sheet  strength.  Provide  the  NPT  with 
explanations and argumentation for discussion with the financiers and 
development partners. 
(b) Provide the NPT with a detailed presentation of the financial assumptions 
used for the calculation of the transmission revenue, with their associated 
standard values.

2.  Specific Deliverables 
5.  The specific deliverables of the advisor are 
(i)  comments on the regulation, 
(ii)  training of NPT staff on the use of the regulation, 
(iii)  recommendation and proposal on the corporate structure of NPT in the reformed 
power sector, and 
(iv)  producing the TA final report that will collate all reports and notes produced 
under the TA by the other experts. 
 
6.  The specific deliverables of the financial expert are 
(i)  updating the 5-year business plan, 
(ii)  updating the financial management assessment, and  
(iii)  producing a financial model (software) with user guide and training of the staff.  
 
B.  Improvement  of  National  Power  Transmission  Corporation  Efficiency  in 
Implementing Investment Projects: Project Management Specialist (international, 
4 person-months) 
7.  The project management specialist will be selected to handle the following works:   
(i)  design a training package with curricular and material, and 
(ii)  deliver three training sessions of a 2-week training course. 
 
1.  Specific Tasks 
8.  The specialist will design a training program specifically for project managers, project 
team members, and functional managers of the NPT involved in ADB financed projects and 
more  generally  in  official  development  assistance  financed  projects.  After  the  training, 
participants should be able to do the following: 
(i)  Understand  the  knowledge  of  theories  and  principles  involved  in  project 
management.

Appendix 3  11 
(ii)  Design an efficient procurement plan that will minimize the number of packages 
needed to speed up the procurement process and at the same time ensure fair 
competition. 
(iii)  Conduct efficient and fair evaluation of the bids and reporting to donors in their 
respective formats. 
(iv)  Understand the processes and issues in a project. 
(v)  Apply the techniques and skills involved in project management. 
(vi)  Effectively manage the resources and resolve conflict.  
(vii)  Evaluate and monitor progress of the project or subproject. 
 
9.  The training sessions will include a series of lectures and tutorial sessions based on 
international experience with effective management techniques and will cover the following 
topics:  
(i)  Overview: project life cycle and project management principles.  
(ii)  Project organization structure: contract delivery systems, project management 
organization design, procurement, and construction organization; and allocation 
of responsibilities and risk. 
(iii)  Project planning and scheduling.   
(iv)  Project control: time control and cost control. 
(v)  Risk evaluation and mitigation: nature of project risks (schedule, performance, 
design, and site), evaluation of nature of risks, and quantitative simulation of risk. 
(vi)  Environmental and social issues: importance for project development, planning 
for environmental impact assessment and mitigation, and resettlement planning 
and its importance for projects.   
(vii)  Contract management: risk sharing in contracts, standard contract, and 
procurement contract. 
(viii)  Procurement management. 
(ix)  Quality-based management.  
(x)  Project monitoring and evaluation: principle and tools. 
 
10.  Three training sessions will be provided for a total of approximately 40 management staff 
from the NPT and its subsidiaries in three different sessions.   
 
2.  Specific Deliverables 
11.  Specific deliverables for the project management specialist are 
(i)  producing training materials, 
(ii)  producing project monitoring and evaluation tools, and 
(iii)  conducting training sessions.

12  Appendix 3 
C.  Improvement of National Power Transmission Corporation Communication Skills: 
Communication Specialists (international, 3 person-months; national, 6 person-
months) 
12.  The communication specialists will work in partnership with the head of communications 
of the NPT, and will develop a strategy and activities that address  
(i)  a communication strategy, 
(ii)  strategic communications training, 
(iii)  guidelines on communication, and 
(iv)  field consultation. 
 
1.  Specific Tasks 
13.  The specialists will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Prepare  a comprehensive communications strategy that analyzes the current 
situation, including the communications challenges and opportunities, and create 
a  range  of  communication  materials  for  all  stakeholders  and  target  groups 
(development partners, government, population, nongovernment organizations 
[NGOs], etc.). This will involve a comparison with best practice in other countries 
and understanding of legislation in Viet Nam. The strategy to be prepared will be 
for both the project development period and operational period. 
(ii)  Conduct a strategic communications training workshop for NPT staff. This will 
include development of a communications strategy, materials for the workshop 
and for training, and coaching for senior managers and communication officers in 
responding  to  media  queries.  A  type  of  train-the-trainers  program  will  be 
conducted. The workshop will provide communications support and guidance to 
the task team, including strategic communications (internal and external), review 
of correspondence, outreach, and NGO and development partner relations. 
(iii)  Develop guidelines on communication together with national communications 
counterparts  for  holding  consultations  with  project-affected  people.  The 
consultations should be part of a resettlement master plan drawn up by the NPT. 
The consultants will (a) assist the NPT in developing the materials required for 
explaining  the  resettlement  process  and  compensation;  and  (b)  make 
suggestions on the format, content, and support of documentation materials that 
need  to  be  developed  for  communicating  with  the  affected  people,  such  as 
printed material, website, tape recordings and posters, etc. The guidelines will 
include talking points, questions and answers, press statements, briefs, letters, 
speeches, web materials, feature stories, presentations, slide shows, etc.   
(iv)  Carry out consultations in the field on selected ongoing NPT projects together 
with  NPT  staff,  and  involve  independent  observers  such  as  NGOs.  The 
consultation  process  must  be  documented  by  a  report  at  the  end  of  the 
consultation, with some photos and videos.
